post_text:
It’s beginning to look like back-to-school time in many familiar ways.....with a 2020 twist.

As students gather school supplies, teachers across the district are preparing classrooms and learning spaces for remote teaching and learning.

Because she will be teaching from her fourth grade classroom, Evergreen Elementary’s Kimpha Keoborakot wants students to see positive and welcoming messages as they connect remotely for lessons. Love that shiplap paper border, Mrs Keoborakot!

She also got creative in her attempt to find the best way to set up her station for remote classroom learning.

The fourth grade teacher used two crates and a shelf to place her docking station for a laptop.

“This way, I can angle my camera down,” she explains. “I have connected a keyboard and mouse by USB. I also placed my document camera on the shelf for when I'm modeling work. Image Mate software will show both my desktop screen and Elmo screen simultaneously as I share my desktop on Zoom with students.”

It’s Teacher Appreciation Week, and now more than ever it’s important to recognize educators who are going above and beyond to reach our students. From pre-k all the way up to the college level – and all the homeschooling parents too.

This week we thank those who give the gift of knowledge and help prepare Illinois’ next generation of leaders and innovators.

Know a teacher who you think deserves special recognition? Visit https://www.enjoyillinois.com/allinillinois/teachers to complete a simple Illinois contact form. Don't forget to share your story on Instagram or Twitter using the hashtag #AllinIllinois, or upload your content to a site like YouTube, Vimeo, or imgur.

The Illinois Governor's office, Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity, and the Illinois Office of Tourism will use content on social media channels and website, to highlight all the ways educators across the state are helping prepare our kids for the future and provide a sense of normalcy during the COVID-19 crisis.

Dear Parents and Guardians,

Out of an abundance of caution and in response to the rapidly evolving Coronavirus (COVID-19) situation, Benjamin SD 25 will be closing schools and canceling all sports/activities for students beginning tomorrow, March 14, 2020, through spring break with a tentative plan of returning on April, 6, 2020. This includes PALS Daycare. We will utilize our e-learning platform for the next 10 school days beginning on Monday, March 16, 2020 through March 27, 2020.

While we realize e-learning is not a substitute for classroom instruction, we are endeavoring to make it as viable as possible over the next 10 school days. Our hope is to reconvene classes as usual on Monday, April 6 at the conclusion of our regularly scheduled Spring Break. As events develop we will continue to communicate to you any changes and updates. This is a unified DuPage County decision and we are acting on the guidance from our governing agencies in the best interests of keeping our communities safe.

In Partnership,
Jim Woell, Ed.D., superintendent

Applause! Applause! Celebrating Our Young Readers
Some 35 percent of Benjamin Middle School’s students participated by invitation only a special 2020 Benjamin Caudill Book award celebration on March 6.

Pictured are many of the 75 of our 217 students in the fifth, sixth, and seventh grade who read at least three of the 2020 Caudill nominated books and received coveted invitations to the celebration which featured an ice cream social.

The Rebecca Caudill Young Readers' Book Award is an annual award given to the author of the book voted most outstanding by students in grades four through eight in participating Illinois schools.

Named in honor of Rebecca Caudill who lived and wrote in Urbana, Illinois, for nearly 50 years, the award recognizes her literary talent and the appeal of her books.

The Rebecca Caudill Young Readers' Book Award is designed to encourage children and young adults to read for personal satisfaction, and to increase awareness of outstanding literature for children and young people

Club EverGREEN members start the March “Make A Difference” celebrations off with a big push to bring in pop tabs and bread tags in support of local communitywide charity groups.

Through March 12, Club EverGREEN will collect POP TABS in support of Ronald McDonald House Charities, and BREAD TAGS to support Danielle Cares for Chairs, an Indiana-based not-for-profit organization founded by high school students and providing wheelchairs/mobility for children.

Other March activities include a CHANGE WARS challenge March 9-20 in support of an Evergreen family in need; a Hunger Challenge art/recipe challenge sponsored by Students Rebuild March 23-27, the wearing of Make A Difference t-shirts; and the 3rd and 4th grade Make A Difference musical.

Teachers Julie Martinez and Angelica Steinke lead Club EVERgreen members in wanting to make a difference at Evergreen Elementary School.

Congratuations to Benjamin's Too Good For Drugs program grads!

DuPage County Sheriff's deputies present the Too Good for Drugs programs to 5th graders in approximately 26 schools throughout unincorporated DuPage County.

The school based prevention program is designed to reduce risk factors and enhance protective factors related to alcohol, tobacco and other drug use among children.

The Benjamin program is taught by Cpl. Castillo who presented the students with graduation medals. K9 Handler Dep. Culver brought K9 Praise to the event in support of the students and their accomplishment.

A Warm Welcome To New Evergreen Principal
The Benjamin District 25 Board of Education and Board President Vince Engstrom extended a warm welcome at their February meeting to Joe Pisano, newly named Evergreen Elementary School principal, scheduled to replace Laura Pfanenstiel as she retires June 20.

He has served as principal at Forest Park Middle School for five years and "brings a wealth of knowledge and experience in curriculum and instruction, RtI and MTSS models of service and intervention, instructional leadership, collaboration and team building," according to Jim Woell, Benjamin District 25 superintendent making the announcement. He also served previously as assistant principal and a teacher at the school.

Pisano's appointment follows an intensive search and both individual and group interview process involving a comittee of parents, administrators, teachers and support staff.

This fall, Benjamin District 25’s English language learning classrooms were in need of three iPads to help make Betty Nordengren’s kindergarten-8th grade students’ time at school even more engaging, dynamic, and enriching.

In just two short days, her students’ dreams turned into reality through the generosity of a Donors Choose classroom iPad campaign. Her eager students today are enjoying using exciting apps to make their learning authentic and meaningful.

“So far, we have been able to use a green screen app to launch an exciting story writing activity for first graders; Google Expeditions has exposed a second grader to a virtual field trip; and my middle-schoolers have used the Clips program to create their own movies,” reports Nordengren. “Thank you for helping my students dive into experiential learning with their new iPads!”

Thanks to the Benjamin Foundation for Educational Excellence, a number of classroom items purchased with teacher mini grants funds already are making a difference for students across the district.

A padcaster kit and mobile recording studio now helps students produce the BB300 weekly news broadcast and topical presentations, or equipment to record Spanish language weather broadcasts such as the 7th graders did in Spanish class.

Technology including virtual reality headsets/software for the Oculus Go enables students to journey beyond the four walls of their classroom as they explore places, cultures, and more around the globe.

Many more mini grant items are on order and are arriving soon in district classrooms.

A sincere thank you to the Foundation for the mini-grants, and to other groups such as the Benjamin-Evergreen PTA who also work to supply district students with activities and experiences to enhance curriculum and learning which are beyond the district budget.

An Hour Of Code...A Lifetime Of Skills
In recognition of National Computer Science Week (Dec. 9-13), students at Evergreen Elementary School joined millions of other students around the world participating in the Hour of Code working on age- appropriate coding activities.

Preschool and kindergarten students began their Hour of Code by completing simple puzzles, and moved on to solving simple mazes using code.

Students in 1st grade continued to develop their coding skills by solving more complicated mazes and puzzles.

Second graders did a special Minecraft-themed Hour of Code to challenge and develop their coding and problem-solving skills.

In the 3rd grade, students used the Code.org website to develop their own game using code.

A popular coding program called Scratch was used by 4th graders who began by creating a simple program to animate the letters in their name. Eventually they moved into creating and developing their own programs!

Foundation Funds Teacher Mini-Grants

Thanks to the Benjamin Foundation for Educational Excellence, a number of classroom items purchased with teacher mini grant funds already are making a difference for students across the district.

A padcaster kit and mobile recording studio now helps students produce the BB300 weekly student news broadcast and topical presentations. New equipment is in use now to record Spanish language weather broadcasts such as those the 7th grade Spanish classes recently produced.

Soon technology including virtual reality headsets/software for the Oculus Go will enable students to journey beyond the four walls of their classroom as they explore places, cultures, and more around the globe.

Many more mini grant items are on order and will be arriving soon in district classrooms.
